Chapter 8
CONCLUSIONS
At the end of this work it is possible to synthetize the most relevant aspects of the research
developed in the previous chapters and to present some recommendations concerning the
conservation and rehabilitation of the collective dwelling of cooperative housing obeying to criteria
of authenticity. Thus, this chapter is constituted by two parts: the first one, final remarks,
summarizes the main ideas of the work, and the second one presents some recommendations
towards rehabilitation and sustainability.
8.1. Final Remarks
8.1.1. Authenticity a path alongside conservation and rehabilitation
The concept of authenticity has been connected to the international documents on restauration
and conservation, first related to monuments and later concerned with a more modest heritage. A
conceptual base was constructed shaping ways of dealing with the heritage: “What to preserve?”,
“How to rehabilitate?”. The concept of authenticity gained corpus and became more defined.
The buildings destined to be use are voted to impermanence. There are buildings that by their
longevity are a repository of epochs. The preservation of the historic buildings must respect the
uninterrupted course of memory, in order to assure the continuity of their authenticity.
In Portugal, the big impulse in the housing cooperative movement is due to the post 25th of April
1974. From this time onwards the legal and institutional conditions for its thrive were created. In
the last forty years in collective dwelling of cooperative housing, “authorship projects” of
exceptional quality have been built.
CONCLUSIONS
490
The collective dwelling of cooperative housing is a fundamental piece to the discussion of the
city’s authenticity. To consider the city in its authenticity implies taking it as an artefact of human
genius, a singular, specific and non-ordinary artefact of local representativeness and potentially
universal. As a city element, the collective dwelling of cooperative housing fits in that category of
artefacts. The collective dwelling of cooperative housing produced authorship projects for
buildings and urban spaces, full of geniality and singularity.
Given the fact that these buildings are not elected as UNESCO world heritage, the existing
authenticity criteria do not fit this legacy. Therefore it is necessary to define new authenticity
criteria for their conservation and rehabilitation.
Thus our work was guided by the following research question: “What are the authenticity criteria
in the conservation of the collective dwelling of cooperative housing?”
8.1.2. The Methodology
It is not possible to conduct research without having a problem that needs to be solved or a
question that needs to be answered. There are several ways of doing research that correspond to
different points of view. In the post 25th of April 1974, in the peripheral and residual areas of the
cities, collective dwelling of cooperative housing was built, some awarded by their quality. These
buildings constitute our recent heritage and future legacy. Due to the present crises, austerity and
the open ground left by the Exceptional Regulation for Urban Rehabilitation, many of these
buildings will not be preserved, thus facing a rapid degradation. Therefore, it is necessary to
define authenticity criteria in the conservation and the rehabilitation of these buildings. Because
these buildings are not elected as UNESCO world heritage the question that rises is “What are
the authenticity criteria in the conservation of the collective dwelling of cooperative housing?” The
construction of a referential grid is proposed, based on buildings referenced by the National
Housing Institute, presently Institute of Housing and Urban Rehabilitation (INH/IHRU) which can
be used to assess other buildings referenced or not by INH/IHRU.
To answer the starting question the research methodology chosen was the case study, namely
the multiple-case study. Though the case study method can be recognized as a qualitative
research method, it presents circumstances that use a mixture of qualitative and quantitative
evidence. Through the multiple-case study the referential grid was fine-tuned.
For Yin (2010) the case study is a form of differentiated empiric research (cf. YIN; 2010; p. 35).
This investigation is enriched by the use of blended methods, that is, the case study can be
complemented with other methods that have the same research questions, hence strengthening
CONCLUSIONS
491
aspects of the case study commonly addressed as weakness of the research method (cf. YIN;
2010; p. 87).
To answer our research question we tried to define those criteria through the analysis of the
international documents and charters, such as the Venice Charter (1964), the Nara’s Document
(1994) and UNESCO Operational Guidelines of 2012. From this resulted authenticity criteria still
focused on the reality of the conservation of a heritage eligible as world heritage. The contact with
specialists, resulting from Delphi method, allowed us to perceive the need to redefine the
authenticity criteria in the Mediterranean framework and specifically, in the Portuguese context
(Portugal being an European country located in the Iberian Peninsula, facing the Atlantic Ocean,
but immersed in the cultural heritage of the Mediterranean Basin) and focused on the heritage
reality of the object of study.
Firstly, to test this new round of authenticity criteria, a pre-test case study was chosen, the urban
complex of Caselas, in Lisbon, by Justino Morais, INH Honourable Mention 1989. From this
resulted six criteria. These new criteria were applied to other case studies, drawing a temporal
series, thus showing a geographical-chronological “portrait” of Portugal. To diminish the number
of variables urban complexes catalogued by INH/IHRU Prizes as plurifamiliar dwellings in a row
were analysed. The case studies are: INH 1992 Prize, Matosinhos (2nd phase), by Jorge Moniz
and José Figueiredo; Honourable Mention 1992, in Faro, by Lopes da Costa; INH Prize 1996, in
Massarelos, by Francisco Barata and Manuel Fernandes Sá; the Almada Integrated Plan, by
Cruz Henriques and Marcelo Galego, Honourable Mention INH 2001; the Zambujal Integrated
Plan by Carlos Carvalho, INH Prize 2004; Ponte da Pedra (2nd phase of construction), by
António Carlos Coelho, INH/IHRU Prize 2007; urban building in Santiago in Aveiro, by Francisco
Ferreira Simões, IHRU Prize 2009.
To confirm and reinforce the criteria, they were reviewed using of the Delphi Method and they are
applied in non-referenced INH/IHRU collective dwelling of cooperative housing buildings: the
urban complex in Carcavelos, 1990, from architectural office ‘Percurso’ and the urban complex of
Rua do Casalinho da Ajuda, Lisboa.
Finally, the final criteria achieved were tested and validated by two INH/IHRU referenced case
studies, one in Chelas, in Lisbon, and another in Senhora da Hora, in Matosinhos. The findings of
the two final cases reinforce the set of criteria achieved, showing their applicability to similar
buildings referenced or not.
CONCLUSIONS
492
The origin, the building to let
The collective dwelling is a typology whose origin goes back in the centuries, particularized in the
figure of the building to let. Though history and architecture are processed in an uninterrupted
path in order to characterize and to assure the conservation and rehabilitation of these buildings it
is necessary to define building types.
The 16th century to the 1st half of the 18th century buildings
From the 16th century to the 1st half of the 18th century, the division of the city’s spare land in
urban plots correlates to careful planning of the area and to the appearance of a organizational
pattern of a multi-family building: the building to let. The legislation of the Old City’s by-laws
defined the conditions for letting dwellings and the minimum occupation per building. and refers to
The document of 1785 of the City’s by-laws of Bahia (Brazil), for the construction of houses show
us a type of building vertically organized in loja, sobreloja, first floor and second floor, similar to
those of Lisbon in the 16th century to the 1st half of the 18th century.
The regulations defined a pattern image for the building’s façade and the interior of a dwelling as
well as their building materials: chestnut wood floorboards, wooden roof deck, and a wooden floor
above the bottom chord of the roof trusses. Additionally the legislation stipulated the existence of
a chimney and masonry benches in each dwelling. The regulations also defined the thickness of
the walls (2.5 spans), the layout of the doorframes, the levelling of the urban plot and the stepping
pattern of the quarter’s façades whenever the ground slope presented more than 5 spans.
The regulation of the length and width of the buildings materials, by the Weights and Measures
Amendment of 1499, produced precise measures and rhythms in the façades and in the internal
layout of the building. The sense of pattern is reinforced by the urban legislation in expressions
such as: everything must be done according to a unique plan, as outlined by the Senate's
building constructor, a building inspection which does not respect the ornate and beauty of the
city cannot exist.
The iconography and the best preserved buildings from the 16th century to the 1st half of the 18th
century give a precise image of the building to let in what concerns the façade’s top, roofs,
window shutters and balcony shutters, doors, garrets, openings, Lisbon´s armorial bearings,
lessee stone boards.
Two groups of buildings appear: one from the 16th and 17th centuries and another from the 1st
half of the 18th century. For the first group three main types of the "building to let" emerged: one
resulting from the initial urban plot (35-39, 31-33, 27-29, Rua da Bica do Duarte Belo), another
resulting from its division (12-14,Travessa da Rua dos Pescadores) and a third obtained by the
CONCLUSIONS
493
addition of another pattern urban plot. For the 1st half of the 18th century two types of buildings
can be distinguished: the ones produced by Casa do Risco, represented by Rua dos
Bacalhoeiros 8, and the others non related to it, illustrated by the façades’ plans for a building to
be constructed in Rua dos Ourives (D. João V’s reign). This model of big building to let presents
60 spans of façade length, resulting from a double urban plot, and three to six floors high.
The demographic studies on Lisbon and Guimarães for the above mentioned period, the post
mortem inventories plus the information on the human geography in the Bairros Ocidentais of
Lisbon revealed that the average of children per couple (4,56), the prolonged nursing period and
the rare presence of slaves in the common family matched with the number of compartments
found in the most typical buildings to let (3 or 4 compartments). The crises in the XVII century, the
annual exodus of people to Brazil, the loss of many men during the war against Spain and the
Lisbon 1721 plague confirmed that kind of internal layout for the majority of the dwellings.
However, there are also dwellings with a single compartment, as in 12, Travessa da Laranjeira
and more complex ones, according to the financial status of the tenant (Matos 2003).
The pombalino building (1758-1860)
The standard pombalino building to let was five floors high: on the ground floor were located the
shops and in the upper floors the dwellings; the higher floor had garrets built in the alignment of
the other openings. The buildings constructed in the main streets had bay-windows in the first
floor and sill-windows on the second and third floors. Those built in the secondary streets had sill-
windows in all the floors. The façade´s plaster was painted. The stone pilasters were put in the
corners of the quarter, separating each building to let. Ashlars were put around the openings.
Within this normalization the buildings could vary regarding the gauges, the dimensions of the
openings and the façade´s finishes, i.e., the design detail, the type and quality of the building
materials employed (Teixeira & Valla, 1999).
Despite Marquis de Pombal’s prohibition to build outside the limits of the city, outside Baixa
Pombalina the leasers built in urban plots demarcated at their own will, following the order and
symmetry characteristic of João V’s reign. In the building to let, this empiricism coexists with the
erudite principles applied to the Baixa Pombalina (Rossa, 1998, Rossa et al, 2001).
Although forbidden by Marquis de Pombal, after his dismissal in 1777, the mashrabiya persisted,
as confirmed by the notarial register of December 31rst, 1791. The edit of March 9th, 1835 forbids
them, as well as the wooden ceilings that covered the superior beams of the roofs (Serrão, 1995).
In 1930, the legislation for the city of Lisbon still forbids the construction of mashrabiya that
balance out of the door-posts.
CONCLUSIONS
494
The pombaline plan for Lisbon foresees sidewalks, whose construction will free the façade from
the imposed 16 spans for the passage of carriages.
In 1834 we find a disuse of lessee stone boards, presumably due to the extinction of the religious
orders, with the consequent extinction of administrative division of the city in parishes, as well as
the advent of the division of the city in postal districts due to the appearance of the post office in
Lisbon in the first decenniums of the 19th century (Matos, 2009).
From 1850 onwards the revetment of the façades with glazed tiles became current (Carvalho,
1997). They are a reflex of the romantic Lisbon (Silva, 1997). The embossed glazed tiles in their
bas and full embossed version would make their appearance in the 2nd half of the 19th century
The use of jalousies and royal entablements with line effect iron bars, as well as iron bars in the
windows of the “logeas” persisted throughout the pombaline period (Matos, 2009).
A wooden structure, the pombaline cage (“gaiola”), is used in the construction of the buildings
since the second half of the 18th. century till the gaioleiros era. The use of a wooden structure to
support the building is not new, it goes back to the romans and also appears in Lisbon medieval
buildings, namely in Rua dos Cegos 20-22 (Matos, 2003). Under different names the Europeans
knew this constructive system. What is new is the systematic use of the pombaline “gaiola”, its
improvement and norms of applications to enhance its efficiency (Mateus, 2004). The “gaiola”
was laid on the basement of the ground floor or of the foundations, with the help of ground-sills
reinforced with stone-bolts. It was also fixed to the stone masonry corners by using bolts made of
iron sheet. The gable walls were basically frontal walls and generally common to two buildings.
Their thickness rarely changed as it progressed to the upper floor. The gable walls used the same
pug masonry of the frontals (Lopes, 2005).
On the 3rd of June of 1859, the city determines that all the civil constructions could not have
angles at the cross-roads and round chamfers with a specific radius should be adopted onwards.
(Annaes do Município de Lisboa, 1856-59, Junho de 1859, pp. 322-323).
A prospectus of houses to be built, dated from 17 August, 1860, shows us the introduction of the
platband in the façades. This element would become common. The use of the Moorish roof,
referred in the documents between 1850 and 1870, persisted combined with the use of the
platband. In the last quarter of the 19th century the Marseille tile, used in the First Portuguese
Modernist Movement, would be introduced. As for the organization of the buildings in the quarter,
the prospectus of the type section of the Baixa Pombalina streets present the relationship
between the inner yard and the building. The inner yard results in a central space in the quarter
which allows the illumination of the rear façades and the dumping of the waters through
appropriate plumbing (Matos, 2009).
CONCLUSIONS
495
Due to the slowness in the reconstruction of the city after the 1755’s earthquake, the Baixa
Pombalina presents a variety of situations regarding the internal layout of the buildings, the
modules by urban plot and the location in the quarter (Barreiros, 2004). A work contract of
December 30th, 1791, for an urban plot in Rua dos Ourives do Ouro, shows us the internal image
of a dwelling: a kitchen with its fixed stone slabs for pots, principal rooms, the dining room and the
corridors (ANTT, Registos Notariais de Lisboa, Cartório 11, Cx. 153, livro 7120).
The standard dwellings of Baixa had six rooms, including the kitchen with direct access to the
stairs, inscribed in a rectangle. Some dwellings would have an extra room with direct access to
the stairs: the independent room. In the narrower urban plots there are fewer divisions per
dwelling. These “minimum dwellings” have straight flight stairs in order to reach the first landing,
where are located the doors that give access to the left and right side dwellings if the number of
modules of the urban plot permits. From there it develops into two parallel flights of stairs
(Barreiros, 2004). Outside of the Baixa limits, the pombalino building has to adapt to the scale
and urban plots where it is built, presenting earlier typologies or mixed solutions which are distant
from the models conceived by Eugénio dos Santos and Carlos Mardel (Carita, 1994). We present
the types of internal layout considering the private space inferred from the 1780-86 post mortem
inventories. Madureira (1992) shows types of dwellings closely connected to the socio-
professional profile of its owners: dwellings with substructures for having meals in room, with
mobile stalls with two flaps or dwellings with stalls with six rounded feet; dwellings with
substructures adaptable to have meals in a room, with stalls with a minimum length of 5 spans,
but with indeterminate function; dwellings without substructures to have meals, with a single piece
of furniture with 5 or more spans of length; and dwellings without any type of furniture
(Madureira,1992).
Concerning the interiors, from 1758 till 1860, the notarial register from 1791 gives a perspective
of the interiors of the pombalino building: the first flight of stairs would be made of squared stone;
all the kitchens would have fixed slab stones for pots; there would be cupboards and coal-cellars;
there would be a hierarchy of the glazed tiles in the front rooms, alcoves, kitchens and corridors
according to the high and proportion of the compartments, which would applied to the first floor
and the above; the rooms would be floored with the best and thickest wood of Scotch pine; as for
the doors, they would be specified regarding their colors and typology (Silva, 1997).
The gaioleiro building (1861-1930)
The gaioleiro building shows specific constructive and morphologic characteristics. In the late
1870’s with the expansion of Lisbon towards the north and the need to construct fast and at a low
CONCLUSIONS
496
price, there was a decrease of quality in the building construction (Monteiro, 2012). The gaioleiro
used an adulterated model of the pombaline cage. The exterior walls were made of common
uneven stone mortared masonry, and the gable walls and inner yards of solid brick. The interior
walls present brickwork confined to an orthogonal grid of uprights (in the contours of doors and
tops) and transoms (at the level of the floor and intermediate levels), or wall paneling made of
plastered planks. The pavements were in pine or Scotch pine perpendicularly oriented to the
façade. The use of beams of one piece comprising the entire depth of the building is recurrent.
The beams lay on the masonry walls, frequently without the recourse of the ground-sills or are
simply nailed to the ground-sills. A systematic abandon of the joineries typical of the plastered
pombaline building occurs. In the rear façade balconies and verandas are built, supported by
slender iron structures, with pavements of beams shaped in I or inverted T and small domes of
solid brick masonry, interconnected by a mortar of lime and cement. The thinning of the main
walls is usual, as we progress from the ground floor (0.80m - 0.90m) to the top floor (0.30m). In
the exterior coatings, stone socles are replaced by mortar socles. Glazed tiles often cover the
façade. The foundations are made of a masonry of a mortar of sand and lime, in a proportion of
one part to its double (Appleton, 2005).
The General Regulation of the Urban Construction for the city of Lisbon of 1930 established bland
shade colours for the façades and required emergency stairs in the rear façades of the buildings
with two or more floors or more than two individuals per floor, unless the building already had a
main and a secondary stair. The decree of the 20th of October of 1865 will shape the corners of
Lisbon and Porto buildings in a round or straight chamfer, a praxis that persisted in Estado Novo,
as respectively shown in Largo do Rato 16-16 C/Rua de S. Bento 712-714 and Avenida da
República 36-36 E/Avenida Visconde Valmor 27-27E (1948). Since 1868, the façades recurrently
present platbands. The Regulation of 1930 shaped them according to their construction materials
and high.
The notarial register of 5 August, 1861 allows us to re-establishing the date of the appearance of
the gaioleiro building between 1861 and c.1930, when a new model of staircase is established
(1861), and the date of the approval of The General Regulation of the Urban Construction for the
city of Lisbon. The latter would be the reason for the appearance of the “codfish tail” building plan,
setting a new model of building to let.
In 1758 a description of a notarial register gives us a model of a typical pombaline staircase. In
1858 the stairs appear associated to a skylight. In 1861 a model of staircase prevails with a
paved entrance with an arch preceding the staircase. In 1869, that model is detailed: the
staircase would be in modern style of curved pieces of woods; the entrance would be paved in

black and white stone in a chessboard pattern; the first step would be in square stone as the arch
(ANTT, Registos Notariais de Lisboa, Cartório nº 1, maço 69, Cx 147, livro 685, fl. 62v-64v). The
prospectus of 1867 of a building in Rua Luz Soriano 75 presents a staircase with its well. In 1902
and 1903, this model is reinforced. The regulation of 1930 enhanced it, defining the minimum
width of the stairs and increasing the width of the well (Matos, 2009).
As for the compartments of the dwelling, the notarial register of the 5th of August of 1861 lets us
know that each floor will have a living-room, a sitting room, three bedrooms, a dining-room with a
window-sill near the inner yard, a kitchen with a bay window to the same inner yard (ANTT,
Registos Notariais de Lisboa, Cartório nº 1, maço 79, Cx 144, livro 667, fl. 73v-75v). The
regulation of 1903 also places the kitchen near the inner yard as well as the vestibules and ante-
chambers. The 1902 regulation defines that the semi-basement floors must have their own
latrine, a place for the oven and its chimney (Matos, 2009). The dining-room was located near the
kitchen. From the corridor one may have access to all compartments including the interior rooms
(forbidden in 1903). Near the entrance door were located the living rooms, whose windows had a
view to the streets. The bathroom was near the dining room and the kitchen. The illumination of
the corridor is given by fan-lights. The number of compartments per dwelling varied between six
and eight (Serrão & Marques, 2004). There would be an independent room which opened directly
to the staircase. The regulation of 1930 establishes that every room must have a door or window
opening directly to the exterior, unless it is contiguous to two other compartments with openings
or doors with fan-light.
As we nearer the 20th century, the legislation has lesser references regarding the colors and
materials of the interiors of the dwellings. In 1930 this information is almost focused on the
bathroom and the kitchen. In1858, in a pombaline context, the pavement of the kitchen should be
in timber of the region. In 1863 there is a novelty: the revetment of the interior of the chimney with
glazed tile. In 1930 there is a change: the kitchen should be covered with glazed tiles or other
waterproofed material of easy washing till 1.50 m above the pavement. The pavement of the
kitchen and the balconies connected to it should be made of non-putrescible and incombustible
materials. The same type of material should be used in the bathroom and balconies connected to
the kitchen. In 1863 we know that the doors and door-posts of the living rooms and little living-
rooms should be painted in white and varnished, and the others in orange or another color that
pleases the owner. As for the ceilings, in 1865 that they should be in Scotch Pine, plastered as
the walls tile. The notarial registers of 1866 and 1869 show a change in the ambience of the
compartments: in 1866 they were lined with wallpaper tile; in 1869 they showed moldings in the
CONCLUSIONS
498
coves and a fleuron in the middle of the ceiling in the most important rooms of the dwellings
(Matos, 2009).
The Estado Novo Building (c.1930 – c.1950)
The emergence of Estado Novo would establish a new model of building to let, the “codfish tail”
building, symbolized by the buildings of Rua Carlos Mardel 106 (1939) and of Rua Marquês Sub-
Serra 9 (1938), in Lisbon. The planimetric form of this building plan results from a clever solution
to use the depth of the plot and answer to the limitations imposed by the General Regulation of
the Urban Construction for the city of Lisbon. Generally the Estado Novo building used a
pombaline and D. João V Rein’s language. Principles as the importance of the first floor in terms
of plan and façade persist. However there is a concern about the exposition of the dwelling to the
sun.
This building belongs to the historical constructive period of the first buildings with a partial
structure in reinforced concrete (c. 1930 – c. 1940). They present a mixed structure of masonry
with partial elements of reinforced concrete. The latter is used in the construction of pavements of
kitchens and bathrooms, stairs, balconies, building visors, consoles, pergolas and suspended
bodies. The exterior walls are built in ordinary stone masonry or stonework and the interior walls
are made of brick. The pavements are of concrete and wood.
The Modern Building (c1951 – c.1960)
The Regulation of 1951 would bring the norm of the 45º, responsible for the dissemination of the
rectangular plan of the buildings, the need to position the buildings according to the sun and
dominant winds. This would mean the end of the street-corridor, the acceptance of the principles
of the Modern Movement and a new model of building to let. However, in the historical city the
modern building has to adapt to the urban plot where is built.
In the 1950s the models of the Modern Movement are adopted. The models imported are
assimilated and recreated with originality, which positions the Portuguese architecture in a
particular place. The decade of 1950 is included in the first phase of the historical-constructive
period of the buildings with structure of reinforced concrete (c.1940 – c.1960). In this phase the
buildings have the whole structure of reinforced concrete. For this period the regulations of
reinforced concrete of 1935 and 1943 are important. It is used resistant brick masonry. The brick
masonry is used in the exterior and in the interior resistant walls. The pavements of these
buildings are in reinforced concrete.

8.1.4. Context of the collective dwelling of cooperative housing
The Portuguese cooperative movement appeared in the middle of the 19th century, almost
simultaneously with the English, French and Germanic cooperative movements. In the late 19th
century a new rental market appeared, the Ilhas, in Porto, and the Patios and Vilas, in Lisbon,
precarious dwellings built inside the quarter spare land. Exceptionally social quarters and
quarters for workers were built. However, only in 1918 did the Government start to support the
social housing (Coelho; 2006). From that date onwards this relationship would evolve and define
an architectural production that marked an epoch, in which cooperative housing is included. Two
examples of this turn of the century trend in Lisbon are Vila Rodrigues (1902), the Workers’
Quarter of the newspaper O Século (1905), occupying the palace of the Lançada Viscounts, and
the Social Quarter of Arco do Cego (1918/19-1935), inaugurated in 1934. Towards the early 20th
century the strong connection with urban legislation is undeniable: the façade layout of Vila
Cândida (1912-1915) complies with the legislation for the buildings to let.
The city built under the cooperative movement in the last forty years produced collective
dwellings, often transforming residual areas into urban spaces with architectonic quality.
Cooperative housing production continued until the turn of the millennium, providing housing
solutions and fighting for the right of every individual to a dwelling.
The cooperative movement spread out around the world; therefore we presented the Cooperative
movement in some European countries and elsewhere in the world.
In Spain cooperative housing appeared in 1911. It was regulated by the Low-Cost and Economic
Houses Act. The Cooperative Act of 1942 led to the creation of the National Cooperative Housing
Union in 1957. The rapid growth of the population in the 1970s and 1980s resulted in the
CONCLUSIONS
501
industrialization of the big cities and in a housing deficit. The housing cooperative growth focused
on the construction of subsidized housing. The boom in housing construction brought difficulties
to cooperative housing. The Cooperative Act of 1999 enabled cooperatives to act more efficiently
on the market.
In Sweden cooperative housing, also known as tenant ownership, was an answer to the existing
housing deficits and real-estate speculation. In 1923 the organization of tenants founded the HSB
Risforbund to promote and support of the development of cooperative housing. Tenant
ownership, using the model mother-daughter, was very successful. This model was used to build
a great number of cooperative associations. After the Second World War, tenant ownership
organizations were crucial to the development of the housing market. In 1945 Sweden decided to
provide the same kind of subsidies to rental housing, cooperative housing and private ownership.
This enabled citizens to choose the type of dwelling that best suited their family. Mechanisms to
prevent real-estate speculation were created and direct subsidies for cooperative housing were
made available to any citizen. These were abolished in 1990 and the financing system was
reorganized.
In The United Kingdom, building dwellings for their members was one of the main goals of The
Rochdale Pioneers, the founders of the Cooperative Movement, recognized in 1844. In the 1920s
and 1930s two forms of housing tenure were available: council housing for workers and home
ownership for sale to the emerging middle classes. From the end of the Second World War until
the middle of the 1970s prevailed the encouragement for the acquisition of individual home
ownership, through tax relief on mortgage interest and the creation of a large portfolio of council
housing. In the 1960s, co-ownership cooperative housing was managed by the dwellers/residents
themselves. In the 1970s and 1980s, housing cooperatives with the assistance of governmental
programs provided dwellings for the middle class and low-income families. In the 1990s the
development of cooperative housing almost ceased.
In Chile the cooperative movement was created in answer to an excluding system and it tried to
correspond to the specific needs of its members. Chile´s cooperative movement presented
several phases: initial phase (1887-1924) ? the first cooperatives were created ?, legal initiative
phase (1925-1963) ? promulgation of the first legislation for cooperatives?, State development
phase (1964-1970) ? cooperative development was undertaken by the State ?, Ambiguity phase
(1971-1974) ? this phase corresponded to Salvador Allende’s government, in which cooperative
housing was not a priority ?, crises and re–planning phase (1975-1989) ? as a result of the
establishment of the dictatorship there was an involution of the cooperative movement in Chile ?,
present-day phase (1990-2014) - since the return of democracy the cooperative sector has

progressively gained its autonomy. From 2000 until 2010 the government restructured the
housing policy, creating the New Policy for Housing.
In 2000 the architect Alexandro Aravena created Elemental, a for-profit company with social
interest. Its shareholders are the Universidad Católica de Chile, the Chilean Oil Company and the

As for Portugal, In the Portuguese architectural production there is a strong weight of the
architecture made in the North of the country, which was internationalized at a European and

8.1.5. Integrated Conservation and Rehabilitation, from Europe to Portugal
The integrated conservation had its origin in the Italian progressist urbanism of the 1970s. The
systematization of its principles took place in 1975, in the Amsterdam Declaration. From then
untill now different authors tried to define the concept of integrated conservation. For Choay it is a
way of conservation, restauration and rehabilitation of buildings and ancient sites in order to
readapt them to the functions of modern life. Jokileto (2002) sees it as something that is achieved
by the use of sensible restauration techniques and for the adequate choice of functions, taking in
consideration the plurality of economic and cultural values in order to obtain balanced
judgements. The ways of approaching the integrated conservation changed in accordance to the
planning paradigms, namely the sustainable development.
In the 1990s there is a new model of development based on the preservation and qualification of
the resources and heritage of the past, to transmit it to the future generations, focused on the
people and their quality of life. The stress is now on the qualification and rehabilitation of the
natural and built landscape, on the natural and built heritage. The social and environmental
matters consolidated focusing on the concepts of social exclusion and sustainable development.
Urban rehabilitation is seen as an instrument of these two subjects, working with them in order to
achieve a new model of development.
In the decade of 2000, the contribution of the urban rehabilitation to sustainable development
regards: the territorial cohesion and the qualification of the urban environment, avoiding the urban
CONCLUSIONS
504
sprawl; the use of human and physical resources of the urban areas; the increase of the
attraction of the cities while preserving the natural and cultural heritage. The importance of the
cities and the rehabilitation were widely recognized at an European level. The recognition of the
value of the central parts of the cities brought pressures into the urban centers. Efforts were
developed to create new forms of protection of the urban heritage and the urban landscape.
In the course of the 20th century several urban rehabilitation experiences stand out, namely
Berlin, Bologna, and the ones that took place in Spain.
After the destruction of the Second World War several reconstruction operations took place in
Germany, the majority of them favoring urban renovation. With the purpose of returning to the city
centers, during the Cold War, the Internationale Bauausstellung Berlin (IBA 1979/87) appeared in
Berlin. Its goal was to experiment new strategies combining urban renovation and rehabilitation.
In Berlin the post-war urban renovation occurred in non-occupied soil or in urban soil.
The urban interventions in Bologna aimed at stopping the expulsion of the inhabitants from of the
historical city by providing low-cost housing to low-income families. Urban interventions also
aimed to control the expansion of the city of Bologna, fighting real-estate pressure by using
specific policies, such as the implementation of rigorous land management and control.
The Spanish Basic Studies on several urban nucleuses, made it possible to improve
methodologies and strategies of urban intervention. The creation of Areas of Integrated
Rehabilitation made it possible to solve habitableness problems, rehabilitate heritage, and fix
deficits in community services. The dynamism of the 1980s and 1990s regarding the classification
of several Spanish cities as World Heritage (for example, Toledo and Santiago de Compostela)
placed Spain at the centre of the discussion of urban policies and preservation of heritage.
In Portugal, in the Estado Novo period, before the 1960s, there was a praxis that defended the
restauration of the image of the build “as it was” in its origin, centered on monuments. The few
interventions made focused on historical-monumental urban tissues which should be preserved in
their “primitive style”.
In the 1960s a new way of seeing the intervention in the existing city began. However, the policy
of Estado Novo regarding the intervention on the existing city was maintained. In 1974, with the
study for the Ribeira–Barredo area, in Porto, the historical value of the urban ensemble and the
relevance of the preservation of its social reality to assure its identity, character and significance
was recognized. The rehabilitation of the Ribeira–Barredo area would later lead to the application
of Porto historical Centre to the UNESCO’s world heritage list.

Till the end of 1970s and beginning of 1980s a new way of conceiving the preservation of the
heritage and the old urban tissues takes place, which is accompanied by a mobilization of the civil
society.
The Program of Urban Rehabilitation of 1985 would originate the appearance of the Technical
Local Offices (Gabinetes Técnicos Locais, GTLs), which focused on the management of
processes of urban rehabilitation. Due to their activity, the GTLs of Évora and Guimarães are
referential cases. Lisbon had several GTLs, each one for a different historic district, such as
Bairro Alto, Mouraria and Alfama-Encosta do Castelo. In 2004 appeared the Urban Rehabilitation
Societies (SRUs), which fit into a new approach to the consolidated city to foster the urban
rehabilitation and invert the trend of new construction.
The heritage is considered as a way of affirmation of the territory and an existing and valuable
resource that is necessary to protect, preserve and use in an efficient way. The Portuguese built
heritage has a strong identity character. In this heritage it is possible to recognize typical
elements of the region in which it was built as well as the history of the country. Therefore, it must
be preserved and rehabilitated according to rigorous selection of criteria to assure the most
correct combination of resources used in its conservation and rehabilitation. The legacy of the
collective dwelling of cooperative housing produced in the post 25th of April 1974, is part of that
heritage. These buildings, although being cases of informed architecture, present identity
characteristics of the Portuguese way of doing and of the regions where they are implanted,
which gives to this legacy a soul of its own, and, simultaneously, the comfort of the globalized era
of information technology. The legacy is constructed in different historical tissues establishing a
dialog with the existing reality. However, due to the present austerity, the crises and to the gap
left by the Exceptional Regulation for Urban Rehabilitation (2014) many of these buildings will not
be preserved, thus facing a rapid degradation. Due to the impossibility to preserve everything it is
necessary to define authenticity criteria for their conservation and rehabilitation.
Sustainable rehabilitation
Given the dimension of the environmental impacts of the construction sector and the extraction of
material, with the consequent destruction of biodiversity, we must intervene in this sector in order
to reduce material consumption and carbon emissions. It is estimated that buildings produce 35%
of the greenhouse gas emissions. To the energy used in the construction should be added the
one used in the production of the materials, which represents about 10% to 15% of the building
life cycle. On the other hand, buildings and the building environment consume a lot of materials.
This consumption is estimated in 40% of the materials and 55% of the woods extracted in the
CONCLUSIONS
506
globe. To this the residues from the construction of buildings should be added, which are
estimated in 40% of the total of the residues produced.
Given the environmental and economic crises, a change in the construction sector in the various
stages of the building is necessary. It is urgent to evaluate the environmental performance of
buildings. Sustainability must combine an efficiency of resources with aspects related to
productivity and health.
Rehabilitation, identity and authenticity
The heritage is considered a way of affirmation of the territory and an existing and valuable
resource that is necessary to protect, preserve and use in an efficient way. As we saw, the
Portuguese built heritage has a strong identity character, which must be preserved and
rehabilitated according to a rigorous selection of criteria to assure the most correct combination of
resources to use in its conservation and rehabilitation. The collective dwelling of cooperative
housing produced in the post 25th of April 1974 is part of that heritage.
These buildings are destined to be used and therefore voted to impermanence. Although
significant, this legacy, because is a very recent heritage, is little recognized, which may lead to
irreparable losses of the Portuguese memory and consequently of the European memory. To
assure the permanence of this cultural identity it is necessary that the authenticity criteria are
taken into consideration whenever these buildings are being conserved and rehabilitated.
Because the authenticity is connected to the use of those that inhabit the space, the authenticity
can be seen as a question of degree. The authenticity is the highest degree, the one which is as
close as possible of the author’s project.
8.1.6. Case Studies, their analysis and definition of authenticity criteria
To answer the question “What are the authenticity criteria in the conservation of the collective
dwelling of cooperative housing?” we adopt the case study methodology, namely the multiple-
case study, which allowed us to fine-tune a referential grid of authenticity criteria.
We tried to define those criteria through the analysis of international documents and charters
such as the Venice Charter (1964), the Nara’s Document (1994) and the UNESCO Operational
Guidelines of 2012. From this resulted authenticity criteria still focused in the reality of the
conservation of a legacy eligible as world heritage. The contact with specialists, resulting from the
Delphi method, allowed us to perceive the need to redefine the authenticity criteria to the
Portuguese context (a European country located in the Iberian Peninsula, facing the Atlantic
CONCLUSIONS
507
Ocean, but immersed in the cultural heritage of the Mediterranean Basin) and focused in the
heritage reality of the object of this study.
To test this new round of authenticity criteria, firstly, a pre-test case study was selected, the urban
complex of Caselas, in Lisbon, by Justino Morais, INH Honorable Mention 1989. From this
resulted six criteria: setting/location; neighborhood factor; urbanistic and architectonic solution,
building envelope/form/function; materials and constructive techniques; building appropriation.
These criteria are explained below:
a) Setting/location: image of the surrounding area of the building or urban complex, or rural
area in which it is implanted. Immediate expansion zone (capable of modifying the original
intention of the architectonic image of the urban complex or building). Sociocultural e
natural characteristics of the surrounding area which constitute a particular identity of the
place. Sensorial and cultural characteristics of the place.
b) Neighborhood factor: topographical features and architectonic and human geography
characteristics of the surrounding area which increase a “condition” (atmosphere) in the
urban tissue where the building or urban complex is located that influences its state of
conservation/preservation and appropriation.
c) Urbanistic and architectonic solution: urban image of the building or urban complex and its
relation with exterior spaces (when they exist), producing a front with a certain degree of
urbanity and neighborhood, resulting in specific type(s) of public space(s), that is, the way
in which the building or urban complex occupies de soil, the adequacy of the building(s) to
the form of the land, the morphology of the buildings and the urban mesh and the urban
infrastructures, adjacent green areas to the buildings, roads, local parking areas.
d) Building´s envelope/form/function: relation between the building´s envelope or urban
complex, its form and its intended use. The form defines geometries, volumes,
chiaroscuro, proportions, grammars of the building constructing a visual and esthetical
identity of the architectonic object. These relations define edificatory typologies identifiable
in time, resulting from architectonic movements, civilizational stages and different
geographic context.
e) Materials and constructive techniques: construction processes used, resulting from the
historical period in which the building or urban complex was built, reflecting the techniques
and the ways of doing of that epoch, constructing the physical, visual and aesthetical
identity of the building. The intrinsic structure and the characteristics of the materials,
defined in the project, constitute the identity and essence of the architectonical object and
must be maintained.
CONCLUSIONS
508
f) Buildings appropriation: appropriation of the buildings by the owners that can take various
forms, ranging from the cleaning and conservation of the common spaces to the control of
alterations which damage the uniformity of the layout of the building(s) or urban complex
resulting in a negative impact on its (their) façades.
These new criteria were applied to other case studies, drawing a temporal series, thus showing a
geographical-chronological “portrait” of Portugal. To diminish the number of variables, urban
complexes catalogued by INH/IHRU Prizes as plurifamiliar dwellings in a row were analyzed. The
case studies were: INH 1992 Prize, Matosinhos (2nd phase), by Jorge Moniz and José
Figueiredo; Honorable Mention 1992, in Faro, by Lopes da Costa; INH Prize 1996, in Massarelos,
by Francisco Barata and Manuel Fernandes Sá; the Almada Integrated Plan, by Cruz Henriques
and Marcelo Galego, Honorable Mention INH 2001; the Zambujal Integrated Plan by Carlos
Carvalho, INH Prize 2004; Ponte da Pedra (2nd phase of construction), by António Carlos
Coelho, INH/IHRU Prize 2007; urban building in Santiago in Aveiro, by Francisco Ferreira
Simões, IHRU Prize 2009.
The evaluation of the case studies was expressed in a scale with 3 levels of authenticity low (0%
to 25%), medium (25% to 50%) and high (50% to 75%).
From these case studies we can draw some conclusions. As for the criterion setting/location we
verified that the lack of care of the exterior space, more controllable than the interior of the
dwellings, can modify the purpose of the architectonic image which was intended with the layout
of the urban complex.
Regarding the neighborhood factor, independently of the age of the urban complex, a good
neighborhood, a non-problematic human geography has a lot of influence in the state of
conservation of the buildings and in the lack of adulterations. In contrast, a bad neighborhood and
problematic human geography, can lead to adulterations in the façades by adding strange
elements to the original layout project to assure the security of the dwellers. A degraded building
generates in its proximity a focus of insecurity.
Concerning the urbanistic and architectonic solution, it was observed that the introduction of
stairs and staircases in the public space generated by the architectonic object, introduce degrees
of neighborhood and urbanity. The introduction of green areas and public spaces permit a gain of
ludic space and conceiving urban solutions different from the street-corridor. Non-defined or not
well characterized spaces result in no man’s land, which are socially sensitive areas, abandoned
and insecure places. This is all the more worrying as their extension is wider. The physical
configuration of the urban complex, or building, conditions the construction of the exterior space.
This affects the relationship between interior and exterior and between the several points of the
CONCLUSIONS
509
exterior space. In this criterion it can be observed if an urban complex is “open”, inviting to enter,
or not or if there exists blind points in the public space of the urban complex, either generated by
the characteristics of the urban complex or by the continuous livingness and
adulteration/transformation by the use of the urban complex and its urban space.
As for the building envelope/form/function, it was verified that the urban form can generate façade
adulterations whenever the dweller feels that his security might be in danger.
In what concerns the materials and constructive techniques when the used materials are not as
defined in the project by the author, they modify the visual and aesthetic identity of the urban
complex. This happens when a planned management of the use and appropriation of the urban
complex does not exist. That planned management of use and appropriation can be seen in the
more recent buildings, namely in the equal layout of the closing of balconies.
Regarding the buildings’ appropriation it was observed that the appropriation of common areas
functions as a barometer of the place in which the urban complex is located. By these one knows
the degree of security and type of neighborhood of the area. More difficult to evaluate is the
closing of the balconies, because they can be seen as areas of good or bad neighborhood. There
are solutions originated by the façade layout that lead to an adulteration of the façade which are
symptomatic of the insecurity experienced by the dwellers.
To confirm and reinforce the criteria, they were reviewed by the use of the Delphi Method and
they were applied in non-referenced INH/IHRU collective dwellings of cooperative housing: the
urban complex in Carcavelos, 1990, of the architectural office Percurso and the urban complex of
Rua do Casalinho da Ajuda, Lisboa. Their analysis permitted to conclude that independently of
being referenced or not, some aspects are important: the neighborhood factor and the type of
acquisition of the dwelling, as collective dwelling of cooperative housing. The appropriation by the
dwellers seems to be different according to the characteristics of the layout and the form of the
urban complex. There are forms of buildings that favor the adulteration of elements of the façade.
A careful layout of the exterior spaces, inherent to the project, is determinant in the quality of the
urban complex as in the will of the owners to preserve it.
Finally, the final criteria achieved were tested and validated by two INH/IHRU referenced case
studies, one in Chelas, in Lisbon, and another in Senhora da Hora, in Matosinhos. The findings of
the two final cases reinforce the set of criteria achieved and showed that they could be applied to
similar buildings, referenced or not. The final set of authenticity criteria are the following ones
geographic topo natural context, social context, architectonic constructive and materials context,
and functional context and they are explained below:
CONCLUSIONS
510
a) Geographic topo natural context: image of the geographic and topographical features of
surrounding area of the building or urban complex of the urban settlement or rural area in
which it is implanted. Immediate expansion zone, which is the stage of actions and
intentions can modify the original purpose of the architectonic image of the urban complex
or building and the landscape and natural characteristics of the place.
b) Social context: characteristics of the architectonic surroundings which establish space-
behavioral relations that influence the state of conservation/preservation and appropriation
of the building or urban complex. Socio-cultural characteristics of the human geography of
the place and the surrounding area. Sensorial and cultural characteristics of the place.
Way of transforming in a personal manner the built to meet the uses, reflecting an
individual and socio-cultural identification.
c) Architectonic constructive and materials context: urban image of the building or urban
complex and its articulation with exterior spaces (when they exist), producing a front with
a certain degree of urbanity and neighborhood, resulting in specific type(s) of public
space(s), that is, the way in which the building or urban complex occupies de soil,
adequacy of the building(s) to the form of the land, morphology of the buildings and the
urban mesh and the urban infrastructures, adjacent green areas to the buildings, roads,
local parking areas. Construction processes used resulting from the historical period in
which the building or urban complex was built, reflecting the techniques and the ways of
doing of that epoch, constructing the physical, visual and aesthetical identity of the
building.
d) Functional context: relationship between the building´s envelope or urban complex, its
form and its intended use. The form defines geometries, volumes, chiaroscuro,
proportions, grammars of the building, constructing a visual and esthetical identity of the
architectonic object. This relationship defines edificatory typologies identifiable in time,
resulting from architectonic movements, civilizational stages and different geographic
contexts. In this relationship the uses given by the dwellers to the buildings and the
degree of continuity of the original use or the compatible uses in the urban complex or
building are fine-tuned.
These two final case studies provide a very good illustration of the authenticity criteria for the
conservation and rehabilitation of the collective dwelling of cooperative housing, a legacy not
elected as UNESCO heritage. The criteria used in Chelas and Senhora da Hora can be applied to
other cases, referenced or not. The experiences based on these tests show that these criteria
can be used in other Portuguese cities and applied to a similar legacy. Therefore, they constitute
CONCLUSIONS
511
a contribution to the processes of conservation and rehabilitation of collective dwellings of
cooperative housing.
8.2. Some recommendations towards rehabilitation and sustainability
In the 1990s a new model of development emerged based on the preservation and qualification
of the resources and heritage of the past, a legacy to future generations, focused on people and
their quality of life. The stress lies now on the qualification and rehabilitation of natural and built
landscape, and on natural and built heritage. Social and environmental matters have grown in
importance and now focus on the concepts of social exclusion and sustainable development.
Urban rehabilitation is now seen as an instrument of these two concepts, working together with
them in order to achieve a new model of development. In the decade of 2000, the contribution of
urban rehabilitation to sustainable development is concerned with territorial cohesion and the
qualification of the urban environment, avoiding the urban sprawl; the use of human and physical
resources of the urban areas; the increase of the attraction of the cities while preserving the
natural and cultural heritage. The importance of cities and rehabilitation was widely recognized at
a European level. The recognition of the value of the central parts of cities has brought some
pressure into the urban centres. Efforts were developed to create new forms of protecting the
urban heritage and the urban landscape (Pinho, 2009).
Territory is a limited resource that must therefore be protected. To occupy the soil in a
sustainable way is to respect the fragilities of the territory. According to an environmental
approach, the most sustainable option for the urban center is the rehabilitation and renovation of
the city, using the vacant spaces to implement new projects of urban connection, and densify
urban areas. Given the dimension of the environmental impacts of the construction sector and the
extraction of material, with the consequent destruction of biodiversity, we must intervene in this
sector in order to reduce material consumption and carbon emissions. Additionally, given the
environmental and economic crises, a change in the construction sector in the various stages of
the building is necessary. It is urgent to evaluate the environmental performance of buildings.
Sustainability must combine an efficiency of resources with aspects related to productivity and
health. In what regards the urban rehabilitation of public spaces it should favor urban structuration
and integration. It should also aim at the reconstitution of the nearby neighbourhoods, vitalized
urban axis, as well as the correct functioning of activity zones. It should also favor the appealing
and structuring urban elements that facilitate mobility into the city and between the different parts

512
of the city. It should promote the nearby neighborhoods and the dynamism of well-limited public
spaces by creating vitalized quarters and housing complexes combined with the neighborhoods
by urban axis with well-cared building façades. Public spaces should be designed bearing in mind
their particular purpose and their representative and functional aspects.

ANEXOS
Agricultura urbana, sustentabilidade e autenticidade
Definindo Agricultura Urbana
A agricultura urbana sempre existiu. Autores como o arquiteto Gonçalo Ribeiro Telles defendem
a coexistência e o simultâneo desenvolvimento da cidade e da agricultura. Diversos autores
apresentaram diferentes definições de agricultura urbana. Para Veenhuizen (2006), a agricultura
urbana é o cultivo de plantas e a criação de animais para alimentação e ocorre dentro e nos
arredores da cidade. A agricultura urbana completa a componente rural dos sistemas nacionais
de alimentação contribuindo para a sua eficiência usando recursos existentes, e tem um impacto
no sistema urbano, afetando a segurança alimentar, os níveis de pobreza, a ecologia e o sistema
de saúde (cf. SILVA & MONTE in PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; pp. 45-46). Os nomes
históricos dados às hortas urbanas em Inglaterra são vários e são expressão do tempo: poor
gardens, relief gardens, war garden, liberty garden, victory garden, community garden e defiant
garden. As hortas urbanas na generalidade são espaços tomados ao asfalto, são pequenas
reservas de biodiversidade dentro da cidade, reflexo da cultura e do conhecimento populares. No
quadro das crises ecológica e energética atuais permitem aumentar a resiliência urbana
funcionando como ferramentas de regeneração ecológica (cf. VALERO (dir.) p. 49).
Segundo Mougeot (2000), a agricultura urbana é complementar da agricultura rural porque está
integrada nos sistemas ecológico, económico e urbano ? os ecossistemas urbanos. O mesmo
autor refere que não há uma definição consensual sobre agricultura urbana, o que dificulta o seu
estudo. Mougeot refere como características que devem ser incluídas na agricultura urbana
ANEXOS
524
atividades económicas envolvidas, localização, tipos de área onde está implantada, escala,
sistema de produção, tipos de produtos e o seu destino (cf. SILVA & MONTE in PINHEIRO &
VAZ (org.); 2014; p. 46).
Mougeot considera que dado o facto de a produção, o consumo e um possível processamento
de produto ocorrem próximos no tempo e no espaço, sendo uma economia baseada na
produção de pequena escala, a agricultura urbana assim possibilita menos custos no respeitante
a transportes. No que respeita à localização, Veenhuizen refere que a agricultura urbana se
localiza na cidade ou nas suas franjas. Mougeot menciona a importância de definir termos, como
espaço urbano, espaço periurbano e espaço intraurbano. Segundo Vijoen, Howe e Bohon a
agricultura urbana pode ter lugar em qualquer espaço, como espaços verdes, parques, taludes
próximos de autoestradas de diversas formas, topografias e tamanhos. Quanto à agricultura
periurbana, estes autores consideram que em geral ocupa dimensões maiores e ocorre nas
franjas das cidades, entre o urbano e o rural ou em áreas suburbanas de baixa densidade (cf.
SILVA & MONTE in PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; p. 46).
Quanto aos tipos de áreas, para Mougeot (2000) há uma grande variedade de definições, dado
cada autor usar um critério diferente. Este autor descreve a escala e os sistemas de produção
como componentes da agricultura urbana, enfatizando o autoconsumo e a venda. Veenhuizen
(2006) também refere que a agricultura urbana tem uma variedade de sistemas de produção que
vão da produção de subsistência à produção feita inteiramente para a comercialização. Porém,
geralmente a agricultura urbana tem um baixo nível de organização e usa recursos que estão
próximos como resíduos orgânicos para a compostagem e águas residuais para a irrigação (cf.
SILVA & MONTE in PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; p. 47).
Razões para a Agricultura Urbana
As razões para a implantação e prática da Agricultura Urbana são diversas e estão ligadas com
aspectos sociais, ou relacionados com aspectos de saúde, lazer, economia e ecologia. A
agricultura urbana, individual ou comunitária, fomenta a responsabilização e a participação (cf.
PAIVA et al; 2006; p. 263). Para Farr (2013) a agricultura urbana aparece como uma
possibilidade de fornecer recursos para a cidade (FARR; 2013; pp. 180-181).
Segundo Veenhuizen (2006), a agricultura urbana pode também contribuir para a inclusão social
das minorias étnicas ou grupos desfavorecidos, no que refere à integração comunitária e
redução de pobreza. No que concerne ao aspeto socioeconómico, a agricultura urbana pode
reduzir a pobreza urbana e contribuir para o desenvolvimento da economia local. Através da
agricultura urbana, famílias desfavorecidas podem aumentar o seu rendimento familiar pela
ANEXOS
525
alimentação ou redução de despesas com esta ou pelo aumento do rendimento através da
venda dos produtos. Por outro lado a agricultura urbana pode contribuir para a renovação da
cidade e fornecer espaços de lazer e de recriação para os cidadãos (cf. SILVA & MONTE in
PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; p. 49).
Quanto às razões económicas, a agricultura urbana pode ajudar na auto-sustentabilidade de
resiliência, dado os produtos serem produzidos pelos cidadãos e para os cidadãos.
Adicionalmente o fator de proximidade dos consumidores diminui os custos. Como consequência
da proximidade entre o produtor e o consumidor podem ser usadas águas residuais para
irrigação e pode ser reduzido o custo de transporte. Acresce que o uso de lixo orgânico para
compostagem e consequente produção de fertilizante pode ser visto como uma vantagem (cf.
SILVA & MONTE in PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; p. 49).
No que se refere ao aspeto ecológico, a agricultura urbana pode contribuir para a diversidade da
paisagem urbana e ser a base para a educação ambiental da população. Para Simit (2001) a
agricultura urbana contribui para a biodiversidade porque num pequeno pedaço de terreno são
cultivados diferentes produtos usando poucos elementos tóxicos para a agricultura. Acresce que
ajuda a reduzir o circuito de nutrientes-energia porque usa lixo orgânico para ajudar produção
local da população. Adicionalmente a agricultura urbana é um agente de sustentabilidade urbana
dado poder articular-se com esta última de diversas maneiras, nomeadamente possibilitando a
devolução de carbono ao solo ou ajudando na conservação dos recursos hídricos, visto
possibilitar a permeabilidade do solo (cf. SILVA & MONTE in PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; p.
49).
Segundo Veenhuizen, a agricultura urbana pode reduzir o lixo pela sua conversão num recurso
produtivo ? a compostagem, a irrigação com água residual, a permacultura. Acresce que a
agricultura urbana contribui para uma cidade mais verde, melhorando o seu microclima.
Adicionalmente a agricultura urbana pode ser implantada para limitar a expansão urbana da
cidade: através da agricultura urbana e periurbana podem ser criados espaços entre o espaço
urbano e o espaço rural. Neste contexto Viljoen, Howe e Bohon (2005) defendem o conceito de
Paisagem Urbana Produtiva Contínua, isto é, a criação de uma rede de espaços multifuncionais
onde a agricultura suporta e é complementar do espaço construído (cf. SILVA & MONTE in
PINHEIRO & VAZ (org.); 2014; p. 50).
Agricultura Urbana em Portugal
A agricultura urbana contribui para a sustentabilidade e tem um papel na redefinição e re-
conexão das pessoas a um lugar, o que pode levar à reconstrução de identidades,
ANEXOS
526
desempenhado por isso um papel importante na autenticidade no respeitante aos aspetos
humanos.
A Lei do Solo de 2014, baseada nas preocupações atuais de sustentabilidade e o presente
contexto português, vêm alterar a situação. Os proprietários de solos urbanos são obrigados a
dar áreas legalmente elegíveis para infraestruturas, equipamento, áreas verdes, ou em caso de
inexistência ou insuficiência destas áreas, têm de compensar o município. Assim, áreas
anteriormente para construção, são agora espaços não construídos. Estes espaços têm um
potencial imenso para a agricultura urbana e enquadram-se numa cidade que tem de
(re)aprender a congregar o natural, o urbano e o rural numa lógica de urbanismo ecológico.
Contudo, o seu uso deve respeitar as características dos solos, as características adquiridas
pelo seu uso anterior. As hortas urbanas estão a ganhar cada vez mais adeptos nas cidades
portuguesas, como pode ser visto na Rua do Cruzeiro, em Lisboa, confrontando as traseiras de
dois conjuntos urbanos de habitação coletiva de promoção cooperativa. O arquiteto paisagista
português, Gonçalo Ribeiro Telles, tem escrito desde os anos de 1980 tentando alertar para a
necessidade de incorporar o natural e o rural nas nossas cidades.
São expressão do fenómeno da agricultura urbana em Portugal os casos do Projeto Horta à
Porta, no Grande Porto, as Hortas Urbanas em Vila Nova de Gaia; os Parques Hortícolas de
Lisboa; as Hortas Urbanas em Évora, e as Hortas Urbanas em Beja.
